name: OKBQA 2016
tagline: Open Knowledge Base and Question Answering Workshop at COLING
body:
## **Motivation and Description**

The huge and rapidly increasing amount of structured and unstructured data available on the Web makes it both possible and necessary to support users in finding relevant information. The trend moves more and more towards smart knowledge services that are able to find information, aggregate them, draw inferences, and present succinct answers without requiring the user to wade through a large number of documents. The novel avenues made possible by knowledge services are numerous and diverse, including ubiquitous information access (from smartphones, tablets, smart watches, etc.), barrier-free access to data (especially for the blind and disabled) and knowledge discovery. Over the last years, several challenges and calls for research projects have pointed out the dire need for pushing natural language interfaces. In this context, the importance of Semantic Web data as a premier knowledge source is rapidly increasing. But we are still far from having accurate natural language interfaces that allow handling complex information needs in a user-centric and highly performant manner.


The development of such interfaces requires the collaboration of a range of different fields, including natural language processing, information extraction, knowledge base construction and population, reasoning, and question answering.


This workshop aims to join four communities from the areas of question answering over structured knowledge bases, knowledge base construction for question answering, and NLP annotation for knowledge extraction, both from Europe and Asia: the Open Knowledge Base and Question Answering (OKBQA) community ([http://www.okbqa.org](http://www.okbqa.org)) rooted in the Exobrain project ([http://www.exobrain.kr](http://www.exobrain.kr)), the W3C community group for Natural Language Interfaces for the Web of Data ([https://www.w3.org/community/nli/](https://www.w3.org/community/nli/)), the Question Answering over Linked Data (QALD) community ([http://qald.sebastianwalter.org](http://qald.sebastianwalter.org)), and the NLP annotation and resources community from the Newsreader project ([http://www.newsreader-project.eu](http://www.newsreader-project.eu)).


The main goal of this workshop is to join forces in the collaborative development of open frameworks for knowledge extraction and question answering, to share standards, and to foster the creation of an ecosystem of tools and benchmarks.


The workshop will therefore not only comprise short and long paper presentations but also a hands-on session on already existing frameworks, standards, and benchmarking campaigns, as well as a social meet-up.


## **Important Dates**
* Submission deadline: 25 September, 2016 (23:59 Pacific Time)
* Notification of acceptance: 16 October, 2016
* Camera-ready versions of accepted papers: 30 October, 2016
* Workshop date: 11 December, 2016


## **Topics**
Specific topics include but are not limited to:
* Natural Language Interface for Web of Data
    * Browsing Linked Data
    * Question Answering over Linked Data
    * Benchmarking Natural Language Interfaces
    * Term Matching and Entity Disambiguation
    * SPARQL Query Pattern Generation
    * Schema-agnostic Query Generation
    * Discovery of Linked Data Sources
    * Endpoint Profiling
    * Dealing with Data and Schema Heterogeneity
    * Providing Justifications of Answers and Conveying Trust
    * Knowledge Base Design for Question Answering
    * Language Resources and NLP Software for Question Answering
    * Reasoning for Question Answering
    * Natural Language Querying of RDF exposed as Linked Data
    * Natural Language Querying of Web Services
    * User Feedback and Interaction
    * Dialogue Systems
    * Personal Assistants
* Knowledge Base Construction for Question Answering
    * Entity-centered Knowledge Bases
    * Event-centered Knowledge Bases
    * Human Intervention of Knowledge with QA
    * NLP Annotations for Knowledge Extraction and Machine Reading
    * Gold Standard Data Sets and Quality Assessment
    * Indexing and Mappings from Existing Sources (Structured, Semi-structured or Unstructured)
* NLP Annotation Framework for Knowledge Base and Question Answering
    * NLP annotation framework
        * to represent the layers and their structure of language understanding in graph formats such as XML and RDF, including metadata and underlying ontologies
    * NLP annotation knowledge base
        * to access existing annotated NLP resources efficiently and effectively for further processing for knowledge base engineering and question answering



## **Format**

The first half of the day will be comprised of long and short paper presentations on the workshop topics, opened by a keynote speaker with experience in linking computational linguistics and Semantic Web research. The second half of the day will be devoted to demo papers, panel discussions and hands-on sessions.
 
We expect participants from communities related to the following fields: NLP annotations and language resources, question answering, knowledge extraction and machine reading, and linked data and Semantic Web.
 
In addition, we plan a social meet-up on the evening after the workshop. It will be held in an informal setting and will be open for everyone, including presenters and interested participants from industry and other communities.
 
The workshop will also be coupled with an OKBQA platform for sharing the current status of the OKBQA question answering framework ([http://www.okbqa.org](http://www.okbqa.org)) as well as discussing ideas for future developments.



## **Organizers**

All organizers have been involved in a range of successful workshop series on the topics of this workshop, in particular:
* Natural Language Interfaces for Web of Data ([NLIWoD 2014](http://2014.nliwod.org) and [2015](http://2015.nliwod.org)) in conjunction with ISWC 2014 and 2015
* Question Answering over Linked Data ([QALD 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6](http://qald.sebastianwalter.org)) in conjunction with ESWC and CLEF.
* OKBQA Hackathons ([OKBQA 1, 2, 3, 4](http://www.okbqa.org)) 


**Key-Sun Choi**  
Professor, KAIST, Korea  
kschoi@kaist.ac.kr  
He received the Order of Service Merit on Hangeul (Korean alphabet) day on October 9, 2015 for his contribution to Korean language resource and processing and its globalization. He also received the Eugen Wüster Prize in 2014, while having been served for language resource management standards (ISO/TC37/SC4) as its founding secretary since 2002 as well. He has led the Hackathon for Open Knowledge Base and Question Answering (OKBQA) since 2014, and a workshop for Natural Language Interface for Web of Data (NLIWoD) in conjunction with ISWC 2014-2015. His recent research is about machine reading from text called WiseKB under Exobrain consortium, where challenging issues are entity-linking, predicate-linking, knowledge completion, entity summarization, and other knowledge embeddings for Korean language with multi-lingual contexts. NLQ1 shared task has also been started to test the English and Korean NL queries that are expected to be answered against DBpedia or other knowledge bases. DBpedia.co.kr runs under his group’s activities.
 
**Christina Unger**  
Ph.D. Researcher, Universität Bielefeld, Germany  
cunger@cit-ec.uni-bielefeld.de  
Dr. Christina Unger received a Ph.D on computational linguistics from the Utrecht Institute of Linguistics (Netherlands) in 2010. In 2009 she joined the Semantic Computing Group at CITEC at Bielefeld University, where she is working in the areas of NLP and the Semantic Web, with a focus on the ontology-based interpretation of natural language for question answering. She is part of the development and organization of the QALD challenge since its first edition in 2011 and participated in past OKBQA hackathons.
 
**Piek Vossen**  
Professor, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, the Netherlands  
p.t.j.m.vossen@vu.nl  
He is leading a team of 7 researchers. He has a B.A. and a Ph.D. at the University of Amsterdam. He worked in many international projects (Acquilex I and II, Sift, EAGLES, EuroWordNet I and II, EuroTerm, BalkaNet, Meaning, Arabic Wordnet) and national projects (Links, Like, Cornetto, DutchSemCor, From Text to Political Positions, the Semantics of History). He was the site manager in the Sift project and the coordinator of the European projects EuroWordNet and Kyoto. He organised several workshops on wordnets (EACL/ACL in Madrid 1997, EACL/ACL-Senseval in Toulouse 2001) and 6 conferences (Euralex 1998 conference in Amsterdam, 4 Global Wordnet Conferences: 2002 in Mysore India, 2004 in Brno Czech, 2006 in Korea and 2010 in Mumbai, the First International Workshop on Intercultural Collaboration (IWIC) in 2007, Kyoto). He has been an active member of the Ansi-committee on Ontology Standards and the Eagles Lexicon Group, both involved in the standardization of ontologies, wordnets and lexical semantic resources. In 1999, he joined Sail-Labs as a senior researcher and manager, and from 2001 till 2009 he was CTO at another language technology company in Delft, the Netherlands, called Irion Technologies. He is a co-founder and co-president of the Global Wordnet Association (GWA), together with Dr. Christiane Fellbaum from Princeton University
 
**Jin-Dong Kim**  
Project Associate Professor, Database Center for Life Science (DBCLS), Japan  
jdkim@dbcls.rois.ac.jp  
Dr. Jin-Dong Kim is a Project Associate Professor of Database Center for Life Science (DBCLS) where he is leading QA, NLP and Text Mining projects. He is a co-organizer of the bi-annual BioNLP shared task series which focuses on extracting information on biomedical events from literature. He is also a co-organizer of the annual BioHackathon series which focuses on semantic web application to Bioinformatics. Recently, he co-organized the OKBQA (Open Knowledge Base and Question Answering) hackathon to facilitate an open collaboration of QA technology over LOD, and BLAH (Biomedical Linked Annotation Hackathon) to release biomedical text mining resources as Linked Data. He is regularly serving on the program committee of many major NLP conferences including ACL, Coling, SIGIR and LREC. He also edited several journal special issues including BMC Bioinformatics and Computational Intelligence.
 
**Axel-Cyrille Ngonga Ngomo**  
Ph.D. Researcher, Universität Leipzig, Germany  
ngonga@informatik.uni-leipzig.de  
Dr. Axel Ngonga heads the AKSW research group in Leipzig, where he works on topics such as Information Extraction, Question Answering and Keyword-Based Search with a strong focus on structured data. Axel has co-organized the QALD workshops as well as the BioASQ challenges over the last three years. He has participated in the creation of the corresponding benchmark datasets and also co-organized the OKBQA Hackathon. He currently leads the HOBBIT H2020 project on benchmarking Linked Data as well as the DIESEL and QAMEL projects on distributed search and question answering on mobile devices. Axel has served on the program committees of (Semantic) Web and AI conferences including ESWC, ISWC, WWW, LREC and AAAI. He is member of the editorial board of the International Journal on Semantic Web and Information System.
